channel.title: Sykdomspulsen
channel.description: Sykdomspulsen is a real-time analysis and disease surveillance system designed and developed at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH/FHI).

item.title: Auto-Updating Docker-Compose Images (Using Podman)
item.dc:creator: Richard Aubrey White
item.description: Through some simple python coding and systemd services, we have successfully created an automatic update mechanism for Docker-Compose with a Podman backend.

item.title: R-Package "org" (version 2022.7.20) Published on CRAN
item.dc:creator: Richard Aubrey White
item.description: "org" is a system to help you organize projects. Most analyses have three (or more) main sections: code, results, and data, each with different requirements (version control/sharing/encryption). You provide folder locations and 'org' helps you take care of the details.

item.title: Custom Airflow Docker Operator (Poor-Man's Kubernetes)
item.dc:creator: Richard Aubrey White
item.description: Airflow is a platform to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor workflows data. Operators are the main building blocks that encapsulate logic to do a unit of work. We have created a custom Airflow operator that 1) checks a remote YAML file and 2) then takes a decision to do one of two actions. This allows us to create a "poor-man's Kubernetes".

item.title: Tidyverse principles at Sykdomspulsen
item.dc:creator: Chi Zhang
item.description: At Sykdomspulsen we adopt the Tidyverse principles.

item.title: From data to reports: real-time surveillance with splverse
item.dc:creator: Chi Zhang
item.description: In this post we demonstrate how we use splverse to carry out real-time public health surveillance.

item.title: Automated reporting in real-time public health surveillance
item.dc:creator: Chi Zhang
item.description: In this post we introduce how Sykdomspulsen uses automated reports to carry out surveillance tasks.

item.title: R-Package "plnr" (version 2022.6.8) Published on CRAN
item.dc:creator: Richard Aubrey White
item.description: "plnr" is a system to plan analyses within the mental model where you have one (or more) datasets and want to run either A) the same function multiple times with different arguments, or B) multiple functions. This is appropriate when you have multiple strata (e.g. locations, age groups) that you want to apply the same function to, or you have multiple variables (e.g. exposures) that you want to apply the same statistical method to, or when you are creating the output for a report and you need multiple different tables or graphs.

item.title: New Course: Longitudinal Analysis for Surveillance
item.dc:creator: Richard Aubrey White
item.description: Sykdomspulsen has published a short course that teaches students to run "normal regressions" in situations where the data structure would ordinarily prohibit you from running regression models. These situations mostly pertain to clusters of correlated data.

item.title: New Course: Which Stats Method?
item.dc:creator: Richard Aubrey White
item.description: Sykdomspulsen has published a short course that provides a basic overview of general statistical methodology that can be useful in the areas of infectious diseases, environmental medicine, and labwork. By the end of this course, students will be able to identify appropriate statistical methods for a variety of circumstances.

item.title: Sykdomspulsen Receives Prize for Best Poster
item.dc:creator: Gry Marysol Grøneng
item.description: Sykdomspulsen received the prize for best poster at Helse- og Kvalitetsregisterkonferansen 2021.

item.title: Posterpris til Sykdomspulsen
item.dc:creator: Gry Marysol Grøneng
item.description: Sykdomspulsen fikk posterpris på Helse- og Kvalitetsregisterkonferansen 2021.

item.title: We are at Kvalitetsregister Konferanse Today/Tomorrow!
item.dc:creator: Calvin Chiang
item.description: Come chat to us in the poster presentation time slot

item.title: Welcome to Sykdomspulsen
item.dc:creator: Richard Aubrey White
item.description: Sykdomspulsen is a real time analysis and disease surveillance system designed and developed at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH/FHI).
